comment.text: System is working as normal and both the standard and performance kernel test have passed on Intel i7-6850K, 64GB RAM, MSI R9 390 GPU.
WFM.
WFM
works

Works for me.. The Default and Performance Regression tests pass OK.  
AMD 965, x86_64 work station, Plasma DE, X-server, nVidia card GTX 650 (GK107) + nVidia RPM's from Negativo17.

No regressions spotted.

lmbench fails to compile, but it seems unrelated to the kernel.
Works great (ryzen, gtx1070/negativo 17 drivers), regression tests pass.
4.18.13 has been functioning normally. The default tests passed or skipped.
Seems to work fine.
I installed this on my Nextcloud VM and it seems to still be the cloud that is next from the old cloud.

Works as expected.

Performance test case cannot be executed due lmbench compilation issue. See:
https://pagure.io/kernel-tests/pull-request/18
After a reset of my machine I could execute the test case successfully.

Works OK on my x86_64.  Hope to see 4.18.14 soon.

(Is there a reason rhbz 1249364 fix is not applied to the f27 branch?)

bugs.title: After upgrading to latest kernel, GPU AMD RX580 changing performace level doesn't affect it's behaviour

bugzilla.short_desc: After upgrading to latest kernel, GPU AMD RX580 changing performace level doesn't affect it's behaviour

long_desc.thetext:
Description of problem:
After upgrading kernel from 4.18.9 to 4.18.10 switching /sys/class/drm/card0/device/power_dpm_force_performance_level to low doesn't change  cards behaviour.

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
kernel-4.18.10-200.fc28.x86_64

How reproducible:
Every time

Steps to Reproduce:
1. echo '\''low'\'' | sudo tee /sys/class/drm/card0/device/power_dpm_force_performance_level

Actual results:
GPU CPU speed - 1400MHz
GPU MEM speed - 2000MHz
Therefore the card is producing extra heat, consuming more power and vents are spinning.

Expected results:
GPU CPU speed - 300MHz
GPU MEM speed - 300MHz
The card doesn't use extra power because of the low clock, therefore vents don't spin.


Additional info:
Evrything works as in expected results on kernels before kernel-4.18.10-200.fc28.x86_64

$ git log --oneline v4.18.9..v4.18.10 -- drivers/gpu/drm/
93b100ddda3b drm/amd/pp: Send khz clock values to DC for smu7/8
b89c077eff7c drm/panel: type promotion bug in s6e8aa0_read_mtp_id()
1950f800faa1 drm/amdkfd: Fix error codes in kfd_get_process
4841f051b32c drm/amdkfd: Fix kernel queue 64 bit doorbell offset calculation
b0442208f62f drm/amd/display: support access ddc for mst branch
88b8d17d3ab0 drm/nouveau: tegra: Detach from ARM DMA/IOMMU mapping
e293c3e0e60b drm/nouveau/debugfs: Wake up GPU before doing any reclocking
3c266a692dda drm/nouveau: Fix runtime PM leak in drm_open()
4a5dfbca3e03 drm/amd/pp: Set Max clock level to display by default


These were the changes between them related to GPU. Bisection is going to be the best way to narrow this down. This would also be best reported at the FreeDesktop.org bugtracker

(also moving over to graphics for tracking)

93b100ddda3b drm/amd/pp: Send khz clock values to DC for smu7/8 is the patch to be reverted, there is quite a bit of discussion around it on the stable list. Sasha's bot autoselected it, and should not have.

bugs.title: CVE-2018-17972 kernel: Unprivileged users able to inspect kernel stacks of arbitrary tasks

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2018-17972 kernel: Unprivileged users able to inspect kernel stacks of arbitrary tasks

long_desc.thetext:
An issue was discovered in the proc_pid_stack function in fs/proc/base.c in the Linux kernel .  An attacker with a local account can trick the stack unwinder code to leak stack contents to userspace. The fix allows only root may inspect the kernel stack of an arbitrary task.

Upstream patch:

https://marc.info/?l=linux-fsdevel&m=153806242024956&w=2

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 1636352]

kernel-4.18.13-100.fc27, kernel-headers-4.18.13-100.fc27, kernel-tools-4.18.13-100.fc27 has been pushed to the Fedora 27 stable repository. If problems still persist, please make note of it in this bug report.

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7

Via RHSA-2019:0514 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2019:0514

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7

Via RHSA-2019:0512 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2019:0512

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7

Via RHSA-2019:0831 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2019:0831

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6

Via RHSA-2019:2473 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2019:2473

This is an automatically created tracking bug!  It was created to ensure
that one or more security vulnerabilities are fixed in affected versions
of fedora-all.

For comments that are specific to the vulnerability please use bugs filed
against the "Security Response" product referenced in the "Blocks" field.

For more information see:
http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Security/TrackingBugs

When submitting as an update, use the fedpkg template provided in the next
comment(s).  This will include the bug IDs of this tracking bug as well as
the relevant top-level CVE bugs.

Please also mention the CVE IDs being fixed in the RPM changelog and the
fedpkg commit message.

NOTE: this issue affects multiple supported versions of Fedora. While only
one tracking bug has been filed, please correct all affected versions at
the same time.  If you need to fix the versions independent of each other,
you may clone this bug as appropriate.

Reproducers, if any, will remain confidential and never be made public, unless done so by the security team.

Use the following template to for the 'fedpkg update' request to submit an
update for this issue as it contains the top-level parent bug(s) as well as
this tracking bug.  This will ensure that all associated bugs get updated
when new packages are pushed to stable.

=====

# bugfix, security, enhancement, newpackage (required)
type=security

# testing, stable
request=testing

# Bug numbers: 1234,9876
bugs=1636349,1636352

# Description of your update
notes=Security fix for [PUT CVEs HERE]

# Enable request automation based on the stable/unstable karma thresholds
autokarma=True
stable_karma=3
unstable_karma=-3

# Automatically close bugs when this marked as stable
close_bugs=True

# Suggest that users restart after update
suggest_reboot=False

======

Additionally, you may opt to use the bodhi web interface to submit updates:

https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/new
